High-Protein Loaded Potato

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to your new favorite comfort food: High-Protein Loaded Potatoes! If you’re looking for a deliciously satisfying dish that packs a protein punch, you’ve come to the right place. This recipe transforms simple russet potatoes into a hearty meal, perfect for lunch or dinner. With the creamy richness of Greek yogurt, the savory goodness of cheddar cheese, and the crispy delight of bacon bits, these loaded potatoes are not only flavorful but also nutritious. Ideal for busy weeknights or a cozy weekend feast, this recipe is easy to follow and guarantees to impress your family and friends. Plus, with a balance of protein and delicious toppings, this dish is a fantastic way to fuel your day. So grab your ingredients, and let’s dive into making these High-Protein Loaded Potatoes that everyone will love!

Ingredients

large russet potatoes

Choose firm potatoes without blemishes or sprouts for the best texture. You can substitute with other starchy potatoes like Idaho or Yukon Gold, but russets give the fluffiest interior. For faster cooking, you can microwave them for about 10-15 minutes before baking.

greek yogurt

Use full-fat Greek yogurt for creaminess, or opt for a low-fat version if you're watching calories. If you need a dairy-free alternative, try coconut yogurt or a cashew-based yogurt. To enhance flavor, add a squeeze of lemon juice or a pinch of garlic powder.

shredded cheddar cheese

Opt for sharp cheddar for a stronger flavor profile. If you want to reduce fat, consider using a reduced-fat cheese or a cheese blend. For a different twist, try mixing in some crumbled feta or pepper jack cheese for a kick.

cooked bacon bits

You can use turkey bacon or chicken bacon as a leaner alternative. For a vegetarian option, consider using smoked tempeh or mushrooms sautéed in a bit of olive oil for a similar umami flavor. Make sure to check for crispiness; fresh-cooked bacon adds more texture.

chopped green onions

Green onions add a fresh crunch; use both the white and green parts for maximum flavor. If you don't have green onions, chives or finely diced shallots can be a good substitute. For a different flavor, consider adding some fresh parsley or cilantro.

salt

Use kosher salt for better control over seasoning. If you're on a low-sodium diet, consider using a salt substitute or reducing the amount used, but adjust based on personal taste preferences.

pepper

Freshly cracked black pepper adds more flavor than pre-ground. For a twist, try using white pepper for a milder heat or a blend of different peppers for complexity. Adjust to taste, especially if you're serving to guests with varying spice tolerances.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Preheat the Oven

    Set your oven to 400°F (200°C). Preheating ensures that your potatoes cook evenly and thoroughly.

  • Step 2: Prepare the Potatoes

    Wash the large russet potatoes thoroughly under cold running water to remove any dirt. Prick them several times with a fork to allow steam to escape during baking.

  • Step 3: Season the Potatoes

    Rub the potatoes with a little olive oil to help the skin crisp up and sprinkle with salt for enhanced flavor. This step is crucial for achieving a deliciously crispy skin.

  • Step 4: Bake the Potatoes

    Place the potatoes directly on the oven rack. Bake for about 45 minutes or until they are tender when pierced with a fork. For even cooking, turn the potatoes halfway through the baking time.

  • Step 5: Prepare the Toppings

    While the potatoes are baking, mix together the Greek yogurt, shredded cheddar cheese, cooked bacon bits, and chopped green onions in a bowl. This mixture is packed with protein and flavor.

  • Step 6: Cool the Potatoes

    Once the potatoes are done baking, carefully remove them from the oven and let them cool for a few minutes. This will make them easier to handle.

  • Step 7: Fluff the Interior

    Slice the potatoes down the middle lengthwise and fluff the insides with a fork. This creates a perfect base for your toppings. Add salt and pepper to taste.

  • Step 8: Add the Toppings

    Spoon the Greek yogurt mixture generously into each potato. Feel free to top with extra cheese or green onions for added flavor and presentation.

Frequently Asked Questions

What is the best way to wash potatoes before cooking?

Rinse the potatoes under cold running water, using a vegetable brush to scrub off any dirt or residue. Make sure to clean them well, as you'll be eating the skin!

How do I know when the potatoes are fully cooked?

The potatoes are done when they feel tender when pierced with a fork. A good test is to stick a fork into the thickest part; if it slides in easily, they’re ready.

Can I use other toppings besides Greek yogurt and cheese?

Absolutely! You can mix in sour cream, guacamole, or even steamed broccoli. The key is to get creative and use what you enjoy!

What should I do if I don't have olive oil?

You can substitute olive oil with any cooking oil you have on hand, such as vegetable oil or canola oil. It helps the skin crisp up.

How can I make the potato filling lighter?

You can use low-fat Greek yogurt or substitute some of the cheese with additional veggies like diced tomatoes or bell peppers.

Is it safe to eat potato skin?

Yes, potato skin is nutritious and adds fiber to your meal! Just make sure to wash it well before cooking.

What’s the easiest way to slice the potatoes after baking?

Use a sharp knife and slice down the middle lengthwise. Be careful as the potatoes will be hot! You can hold them with a clean kitchen towel or use a fork to stabilize them.

How do I avoid burns when handling hot potatoes?

Always use oven mitts when removing hot items from the oven. Let the potatoes cool for a few minutes before handling them to reduce the risk of burns.

What can I do with leftover baked potatoes?

Leftover baked potatoes can be stored in the fridge and reheated later. You can also mash them, make potato soup, or turn them into potato pancakes!

How do I store leftover toppings?

Keep leftover toppings in an airtight container in the fridge. They should be good for up to 3 days. You can add them to salads or sandwiches!

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

For a lighter version, substitute the Greek yogurt with a nonfat Greek yogurt or even a plant-based yogurt for a dairy-free option. To make this dish vegetarian, omit the bacon bits and replace them with sautéed mushrooms or a sprinkle of smoked paprika for added flavor. If you're looking for gluten-free options, ensure that the bacon bits are gluten-free, and the dish is safe for those with gluten sensitivities.

Pairings

For a well-rounded meal, consider pairing the loaded potatoes with a simple side salad featuring mixed greens, cherry tomatoes, and a light vinaigrette to balance the richness of the dish. Additionally, serve with grilled chicken or steak for added protein, or opt for a vegetarian option like roasted chickpeas for a hearty complement. For beverages, a crisp lager or a refreshing iced tea pairs beautifully, while a light red wine like Pinot Noir can also enhance the flavors of the dish.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the high-protein loaded potatoes hot, directly from the oven. Consider using individual plates or bowls for a more personal touch. Garnish with extra chopped green onions and a drizzle of extra Greek yogurt or sour cream. For a fun twist, serve with a selection of hot sauces on the side, allowing guests to customize their heat level. This dish works well as a main course or a hearty side at a barbecue or casual gathering.

#

High-Protein Loaded Potato

55 min
$5
650 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 2

Allergens:

DairyGluten (if using processed toppings)

Dietary Tags:

High-ProteinVegetarian Option (without bacon)

Cuisine:

American

Course:

Main Dish

Tags:

EasyComfort FoodHealthy

Description

A hearty baked potato stuffed with high-protein toppings for a fulfilling meal.

Ingredients

  • large russet potatoes: 2
  • greek yogurt: 1 cup
  • shredded cheddar cheese: 1 cup
  • cooked bacon bits: 1/2 cup
  • chopped green onions: 1/4 cup
  • salt: to taste
  • pepper: to taste

Date Created:

11/17/2024
